questions.text: The dead body shows the following finding as in image . What is this case?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - Smothering

Correct Answer

Smothering
Characteristics Bruises around the perioral region, nail abrasions around lips and nose, petechial hemorrhages.
Reason Smothering obstructs the airways with an external object, causing characteristic external injuries.

 

 

Reason

Smothering obstructs the airways with an external object, causing characteristic external injuries.

questions.text: The postmortem change seen in the image below corresponds to which of the following:
questions.explanation:
Aspect of Marbling

Description

Definition

Marbling is the mottled appearance of blood vessels seen on the surface of the skin or internal organs after death.

 
  • Marbling manifests as a mottled pattern of dark red or purplish discoloration in the blood vessels of the body.

  • Bacteria like clostridium multiply along the blood vessels & produces H2S gas

  • H2S combines with Hb & forms sulf-hemoglobin.

  • This sulf-Hb stains vessel walls giving greenish, linear branching pattern on the skin [Corresponding to vascular channels]

  • Appearance of marbling = 36-72 hrs after death

questions.text: In a dead body, bloating of face, tongue protrusions were noted along with the findings in the image. Identify the phenomenon:
A child who is a victim under the POCSO Act is brought to the Department of forensic medicine for age estimation. The X-ray image of the hand is shown below. What is the likely age of the child?
questions.explanation:
Upper Limb

Centers of Ossification

Age of Appearance

Age of Fusion

Humerus

Head

1 year

At 5–6 years, the three fuse together (conjoint epiphysis), and at 17–18 years, fuse with the shaft.

Greater tubercle

3 years

Lesser tubercle

5 years

Capitulum

1 year

At 14–15 years, all three fuses with the shaft

Trochlea

9–10 years

Lateral epicondyle

10–11 years

Medial epicondyle

5–6 years

16 years

Radius

Upper end

5–6 years

15–17 years

Lower end

1–2 years

17–19 years

Ulna

Upper end

8–9 years

15–17 years

Lower end

5–6 years

17–19 years

Carpals

Pisiform

9–12 years

-

Other Carpals

The capitate and hamate bones ossify during infancy, with the capitate appearing first at 36th week(3-4 months age). Between ages 2 and 6, the number of visible carpal bones on an X-ray roughly corresponds to the child's age (e.g., 3 carpal bones indicate approximately 3 years old).

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the post-mortem change shown in the image given below?

options.label: A
options.text: Seen within first 12 hours of death

options.label: B
options.text: It occurs due to the accumulation of deoxygenated blood

options.label: C
options.text: It results due to bacterial activity

options.label: D
options.text: It is seen in case of lightning

questions.correct_answer: C. It results due to bacterial activity
questions.explanation:
Marbling

Definition

Refers to a characteristic pattern in the skin caused by decomposition.

Mechanism

After death, bacteria (Option C) spread through blood vessels, decomposing hemoglobin into sulfmethemoglobin (Option B), which causes greenish or reddish-brown staining of the vessel walls.

Pattern

Marbled pattern follows a linear branching pattern, resembling tree branches, which initially appears red and later transitions to a greenish hue.

Onset and Timing
  • Begins to develop 24 hours after death.
  • Becomes prominent by 36-48 hours.

Color Changes Over Time

Skin’s reddish-green marbling may turn dark green or nearly black within 3 to 4 days.

Areas of Marbling

Shoulders, roots of the limbs, thighs, sides of the abdomen, chest, and neck.

Medicolegal Importance

Helps in determining the time since death

Image

Feature

Marbling

Filigree Burns (Option D)

Nature

Postmortem pattern in the skin caused by bacterial decomposition.

Superficial thin, irregular and tortuous skin markings caused by lightning or electrical discharge.

Onset

Starts within 24 hours after death (Option A).

Appears within minutes to an hour of the electrical accident.

Colour

Starts reddish-green and eventually dark green or black.

Red

Site of Occurrence

Blood vessels

Skin surface

Image

questions.text: The phenomenon shown below is typically seen in the case of ?

options.label: B
options.text: Case of suspension or hanging more than 72 hours

options.label: C
options.text: Case of immersion in water for 36 hours

options.label: D
options.text: Case of colliquative liquefaction due to immersion in hot water

questions.correct_answer: C. Case of immersion in water for 36 hours
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Case of immersion in water for 36 hours

Condition

Cause

Symptoms

Treatment
  • Immersion Syndrome (Trench/Immersion Foot/Hand)
  • Prolonged exposure to severe cold (<10ºC) and dampness (common in warfare, trenches, or sea immersion)
  • Affects extremities (feet, hands)
  • Cold, numbness, burning, cyanosis
  • Air drying, protecting extremities from trauma and infection, gradual rewarming by air exposure at room temperature (avoid heat, massaging, or moistening the skin)

questions.text: Identify the following post mortem change:
questions.explanation:
Other Names

Postmortem staining, subcutaneous hypostasis, cadaveric lividity, suggillation, cogitation, vibices, and darkening of death.

Definition

Bluish or purplish-red discoloration caused by the gravitational settling of blood in the toneless capillaries and venules of the dependent parts of the dead body.

Site

Superficial layers of the dermis

Mechanism

Blood in capillaries and venules → Stagnates and sinks in dependent parts due to gravity → Bluish purple discoloration due to deoxy hemoglobin.

Begins

0.5 - 1 hour

Fully Developed

Within 4 hours

Fixation of Livor Mortis

Typically, within 6-12 hours

Confirmation of Fixation

Apply thumb pressure against the skin for a few seconds → Blanching → Livor mortis not fixed.

Primary Lividity

Occurs as lividity reaches maximum intensity between 6 to 12 hours after death.

Secondary Lividity

Shifting of lividity can occur if the body is moved within a few hours after death.

Duration of Persistence

Staining persists until putrefaction begins.

Distribution

Depends on position of the body:

Supine

Appears on the back of neck, entire back, flanks, except areas under pressure (contact pallor).

Prone

Appears on the front part of the body.

Side

Appears on the dependent side.

Head downwards

Appears as a blackened face and neck.

Vertical suspension

Appears on legs and hands (glove and stocking appearance) and external genitalia.

Drowning

Appears on the face, upper chest, hands, lower arms, feet, and calves.

Livor Mortis Absent

  • Excessive blood loss
  • Severe anemia
  • Death from wasting diseases
  • Lobar pneumonia

Medicolegal Importance
  • Helps estimate time of death.
  • Indicates body posture at death.
  • Indicates if the body was moved post-death.
  • Distribution may indicate the cause of death.

Image

questions.text: In an autopsy of suspected poisoning, which organ, along with the stomach, part of the intestine, and liver, is preserved?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - K

questions.text: What is the first postmortem change that occurs in a dead body?

options.label: C
options.text: Greenish discoloration of right iliac fossa

questions.correct_answer: C. Greenish discoloration of right iliac fossa
questions.explanation:
Autolysis

Putrefaction

Autolysis is the self-digestion of tissues caused by the body’s own enzymes after death.

 

Characteristics of Autolysis:

  • Initiation: Begins immediately after death when metabolic processes cease.
  • Mechanism: Enzymatic action leads to cell lysis, altering tissue appearance and texture.

Examples of Autolytic Changes:

  • Clouding of the Cornea: The first observable external change, losing transparency due to cellular breakdown.
  • Changes in Brain Glandular Tissue: The first internal change, where neuronal and glial cells undergo lysis.

Note:

Aseptic Autolysis: Occurs in intrauterine fetal demise, leading to mummification without bacterial involvement.

Putrefaction is driven by bacterial activity, resulting in tissue breakdown and gas production.

Characteristics of Putrefaction:

  • Bacterial Involvement: Primarily caused by Clostridium perfringens.
  • Lytic Enzyme: The main enzyme involved is lecithinase, which breaks down cell membranes.

Stages of Putrefaction:

  1. Color Change:
    • The first internal change is reddish-brown discoloration of the aortic intima.
    • The first external change is green discoloration in the right iliac fossa due to the breakdown of hemoglobin.
  2. Mechanism of Color Change:
    • Hydrogen Sulfide Production: Bacteria produce hydrogen sulfide, which forms a green compound with hemoglobin.
    • The cecum is the primary site of discoloration due to high bacterial activity.
  3. Gas Formation:
    • Gas production leads to bloating, with gases like carbon dioxide, methane, and hydrogen sulfide.
  4. Liquefaction of Tissue:
    • Tissues become liquefied, losing structural integrity, contributing to the characteristic odor of decomposition.
  5. Timing of Discoloration:
    • Discoloration begins within 12-18 hours in summer and 1-2 days in winter, influenced by temperature and bacterial activity.

  • ➤ Post-mortem luminescence:
  • ➤ Emission of light from the body due to bacterial or fungal activity (e.g., Photobacteria and Armillaria).

questions.text: Study of death in all aspects is known as:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - Thanatolog

questions.text: Post-mortem examination of a dead body reveals contraction of the hands with absent primary relaxation. What is this suggestive of?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - Cadav

questions.text: A body brought for autopsy is cold and has developed rigor mortis in all 4 limbs and livor mortis at the back/fixed, but no signs of putrefaction. What will be the estimated time since death?
questions.explanation:
Observation Interpretation
Body cold to touch Suggests death occurred more than 8–12 hours ago (body cools gradually)
Rigor mortis in all four limbs Fully established rigor occurs around 12 hours post-death and lasts up to 24 hrs
Livor mortis fixed at the back Lividity becomes fixed after 6–12 hours
No signs of putrefaction Putrefaction usually begins after 24–36 hours, depending on environment
Feature Details
Other names Cadaveric lividity, postmortem staining, suggillations, vibices, "darkening of death"
Site Superficial dermis (capillaries and venules)
Mechanism Gravitational settling of deoxygenated blood → purple-blue skin discolouration in dependent areas
Onset Begins in 30 minutes – 1 hour after death
Fully developed by ~4 hours
Fixation time Becomes fixed in 6–12 hours
Confirmation of fixation Apply pressure → if colour does not blanch, it is fixed
Primary lividity Max intensity seen by 6–12 hours
Secondary lividity Lividity may shift if the body is moved within a few hours of death
Duration Persists until putrefaction begins
Image

Phase Description Timeframe
Primary Relaxation Muscles are flaccid; ATP levels are 100%. Sphincters relax, leading to the release of urine/feces. 0–1 hour after death
Rigor Mortis Onset Begins as ATP falls to 85%; actin-myosin cross-linking causes stiffening. Appears in smaller muscles first (eyelids, jaw), progresses to limbs. Begins 1–2 hrs; full by 12 hrs
Rigor Resolution Due to proteolysis, rigidity dissipates. Rigor fades by 24–36 hours depending on conditions. 12–36 hours after death

Position Lividity Location
Supine Back of head, neck, trunk, and limbs (excluding pressure areas)
Prone Chest, face, front of limbs
Side Dependent side
Head-down Face and neck blackened
Vertical suspension Legs, hands, external genitalia (glove and stocking pattern)
Drowning Face, chest, hands, feet, calves

questions.text: All of the following changes occur in chronic starvation except?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - Hyperth

questions.text: In medicolegal examination accused 18 year old male claims he is 16 year old. Which joint x-ray should be done?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - K

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding adipocere formation?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Preserv

questions.text: Which of the following eye signs can be appreciated in the image?
questions.explanation:
Part of Eye

Features

Time Since Death (TSD)

Retina (Option B)
  • Kevorkian Sign: Fragmentation or segmentation of blood column in retinal vessels (cattle trucking or shunting)
  • Occurs within minutes and lasts about an hour.
  • Seen using an opthalmoscope.

Few minutes

Vitreous Humor (Option D)
  • Vitreous humor’s accessibility and resistance to putrefaction make it ideal for forensic analysis.
  • Potassium along with hypoxanthine increases due to autolysis of choroid and retinal cells.
  • Potassium levels provide accurate TSD estimates, unaffected by external factors.
  • The Sturner and Gantner formula is used to estimate TSD from potassium levels.

-

Sclera (Option A)
  • Tache Noire: Appears as two yellow triangles on the sclera (base on limbus, apex at medial or lateral canthus), which darken to brown and then black.
  • Caused by desiccation and deposition of cellular debris, mucus, and dust on exposed conjunctiva and the sclera underneath.
  • Forms if eyelids remain open for 3-4 hours postmortem.

3 - 4 hours

Cornea (Option C)
  • Cornea becomes hazy within 2 hours of death due to drying and dust deposition.
  • Delayed for about 2 hours if lids are closed after death.
  • Transient haziness can be removed by applying water, but permanent opacity occurs after 10-12 hours due to decomposition.

Within 2 hours

Eyeball

  • Eyes appear sunken and become softer within minutes due to reduced intraocular tension.
  • Intraocular pressure drops from 10-22 mmHg during life to zero within 2 hours.

Within 2 hours (IOP becomes zero)

questions.text: Cadaveric spasm is seen in death due to all of the following except?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Cadaveric Spasm

Rigor Mortis

Time of Onset

Immediately after death.

1-2 hours after death.

Muscles Involved

Primarily involves voluntary muscles, often limited to a small group (e.g., hand muscles).

Involves both voluntary and involuntary muscles.

Primary Relaxation

Absent- muscles do not go through a relaxed phase.

Present- muscles initially go through a phase of relaxation.

Molecular Death

Absent- no significant biochemical changes at onset.

Present- ATP depletion causes biochemical changes in muscle fibers.

Electronic Stimuli Response

Present- muscles may still respond to electrical stimuli.

Absent- muscles do not respond to electrical stimuli after rigor sets in.

Importance

Causes of cadaveric spasm:

  • Asphyxial death
  • Brain injury
  • Cerebral injury
  • Drowning
  • Dinitrocresol poisoning
  • Excitement
  • Fear
  • Firearm e.g., in suicide

The temperature of the body of a deceased person is found to be 39°C. Which of the following is the most probable reason?
questions.explanation:
1. Disturbed heat regulation

2. Increased heat production (excessive muscle contraction)

3. Excessive bacterial activity
  • Sunstroke
  • Pontine hemorrhage
  • Tetanus
  • Strychnine poisoning
  • Septicaemia
  • Cholera

questions.text: Identify the following post mortem change :
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Sugg

Postmortem Change

Description

Algor mortis

Cooling of the body after death due to the loss of metabolic heat

Livor mortis

Discoloration of the skin caused by the settling of blood in dependent areas

Rigor mortis

Stiffening of the muscles due to biochemical changes and the depletion of ATP

Putrefaction

Decomposition of body tissues by bacteria and enzymes, resulting in the release of gases

Autolysis

Self-digestion of cells and tissues as a result of the release of enzymes

Skeletonization

Process of decomposition where only the skeletal remains, including bones, are left behind

Adipocere formation

Transformation of body fat into a waxy substance under certain environmental conditions

Mummification

Preservation of the body by desiccation (drying out) and limited decomposition

Insect activity

Infestation of the body by various insects that feed on decomposing tissues

Environmental factors

Influence of temperature, humidity, and other external factors on the rate of decomposition

questions.text: Identify the correct pair: i. Mummification 1) ii. Adipocere 2) iii. Marbling 3) iv. Lividity of death 4)
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - i -3, ii-4, iii-1, iv-2

Physiological Findings in Post-Mortem

Description

Livor Mortis

Discoloration of the skin due to the settling of blood after death. Gravity causes blood to pool in the lowest parts of the body, resulting in a purplish-red discoloration.

Rigor Mortis

Stiffening of the muscles after death due to a chemical reaction in the muscles. It starts a few hours after death, peaks at around 12-24 hours, and then gradually dissipates over the following 24-48 hours.

Algor Mortis

Cooling of the body after death. The body temperature drops by about 1.5 degrees Fahrenheit (0.8 degrees Celsius) per hour until it reaches the ambient temperature.

Putrefaction

Decay of body tissues caused by the action of bacteria and enzymes. It leads to the release of gases, bloating of the body, and a strong odor. Putrefaction usually begins within a day or two after death.

Autolysis

Self-digestion of body tissues caused by the release of digestive enzymes from cells after death. It results in the breakdown of cells and tissues, leading to the disintegration of organs over time.

Decomposition

Breakdown of the body tissues and organs through the combined action of bacteria, fungi, and insects. It progresses through several stages, including fresh, bloat, active decay, advanced decay, and dry/remains.

Adipocere Formation

Also known as "grave wax," it is the formation of a waxy substance in the body's fatty tissues during decomposition. It occurs in specific environmental conditions, such as damp and anaerobic (low-oxygen) environments.

Mummification

Preservation of the body due to desiccation (drying out) in a dry environment. It can occur naturally in arid conditions or as a result of intentional or accidental mummification practices.

Maggot Infestation

Presence of maggots (larvae of flies) on the body, which feed on decomposing tissue. Maggots are often used by forensic entomologists to estimate the time of death and postmortem interval.

Postmortem Lividity

The settling of blood in the dependent parts of the body, causing a bluish-purple discoloration. It can help determine the position of the body after death and estimate the time of death.

questions.text: A girl was allegedly kidnapped by a man. In court, she says that she is a major and is married to the man, X ray images of her elbow, wrist and pelvis are given. What is the approximate age of the girl?
questions.explanation:
Bone Region Epiphyseal Fusion Age (approximate)
Wrist (Lower end of radius & ulna) 17–18 years
Elbow (medial epicondyle, lateral epicondyle, capitulum, etc.) 14–16 years
Pelvis (iliac crest, ischial tuberosity) 18–21 years
Clavicle (medial end) 21–22 years (last to fuse)

Bone/Joint

Approximate Age of Fusion

X-ray Findings

Clavicle

Late teens to early 20s

Complete fusion of the medial and lateral ends.

Epiphyses of long bones

Late teens to early 20s

Fusion of the growth plates, disappearance of epiphyseal line.

Sternum

Late teens to early 20s

Fusion of the sternal body and manubrium.

Sacrum

Late teens to early 20s

Fusion of the sacral vertebrae.

Pubic symphysis

Late teens to early 20s

Fusion of the pubic bones, loss of symphyseal space.

Medial clavicular epiphysis

18-25 years

Fusion of the medial end of the clavicle.

Proximal humeral epiphysis

Late teens to early 20s

Fusion of the proximal humeral epiphysis.

Distal radius and ulna epiphyses

Late teens to early 20s

Fusion of the distal radial and ulnar epiphyses.

Distal tibial and fibular epiphyses

Late teens to early 20s

Fusion of the distal tibial and fibular epiphyses.

Lateral clavicular epiphysis

25-31 years

Fusion of the lateral end of the clavicle.

Epiphysis of long bones (certain exceptions)

Early 20s to late 20s

Fusion of specific epiphyses, such as those in the hand and foot.

questions.text: Identify the post-mortem change described below .:
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Sugg


Aspect of Livor Mortis

Description

Definition

Livor mortis, also known as postmortem lividity or lividity, is the pooling or settling of blood in the dependent parts of the body after death.

Time of Onset

Livor mortis usually becomes visible within 1-2 hours after death, but it may take up to 4-6 hours to fully develop.
